ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic triad of obesity, short metacarpals (especially 4th and 5th), and intellectual disability. This is the hallmark presentation of AHO/PHP1A.
Same as AHO, presenting with Albright hereditary osteodystrophy phenotype including obesity, brachydactyly, and cognitive impairment.
Features of AHO (obesity, short metacarpals, mild intellectual disability) but without hormone resistance. Related to PHP1A.
Presents with obesity and intellectual disability, but short metacarpals are not typical. Small hands/feet are more common than specific metacarpal shortening.
Features obesity and intellectual disability. Brachydactyly can occur but is usually postaxial polydactyly rather than short metacarpals.
Presents with obesity (truncal) and intellectual disability. Can have small hands but specific metacarpal shortening is less characteristic.
Features childhood obesity and intellectual disability, but short metacarpals are not typical. More associated with sensory deficits.
